theorem Example_3_5_2
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) :
    A \ (B \ C) ‚äÜ (A \ B) ‚à™ C := by
  fix x : U
  assume h1 : x ‚àà A \ (B \ C)
  define; define at h1
  have h2 : ¬¨x ‚àà B \ C := h1.right
  define at h2; demorgan at h2
            --Now h2 : ¬¨x ‚àà B ‚à® x ‚àà C
  by_cases on h2
  -- Case 1
  apply Or.inl
  show x ‚àà A \ B from And.intro h1.left h2
  -- Case 2
  apply Or.inr
  show x ‚àà C from h2


>>Goals accomplished üéâ


There is a second strategy that is often useful to prove a goal of the form P ‚à® Q. It is motivated by the fact that P ‚à® Q is equivalent to both ¬¨P ‚Üí Q and ¬¨Q ‚Üí P.


To prove a goal of the form P ‚à® Q:

Assume that P is false and prove Q, or assume that Q is false and prove P.

If your goal is P ‚à® Q, then the Lean tactic or_left with h will add the new given h : ¬¨Q to the tactic state and set the goal to be P, and or_right with h will add h : ¬¨P to the tactic state and set the goal to be Q. For example, here is the effect of the tactic or_left with h:


>> ‚ãÆ
‚ä¢ P ‚à® Q


>> ‚ãÆ
h : ¬¨Q
‚ä¢ P


Notice that or_left and or_right have the same effect as apply Or.inl and apply Or.inr, except that each adds a new given to the tactic state. Sometimes you can tell in advance that you won‚Äôt need the extra given, and in that case the tactics apply Or.inl and apply Or.inr can be useful. For example, that was the case in the example above. But if you think the extra given might be useful, you are better off using or_left or or_right. Here‚Äôs an example illustrating this.


example (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : A \ B ‚äÜ C) : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C := by


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A \ B ‚äÜ C
‚ä¢ A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C


Of course, we begin by letting x be an arbitrary element of A. Writing out the meaning of the new goal shows that it is a disjunction.


example (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : A \ B ‚äÜ C) : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C := by
  fix x : U
  assume h2 : x ‚àà A
  define


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A \ B ‚äÜ C
x : U
h2 : x ‚àà A
‚ä¢ x ‚àà B ‚à® x ‚àà C


Looking at the givens h1 and h2, we see that if we assume x ‚àâ B, then we should be able to prove x ‚àà C. This suggests that we should use the or_right tactic.


example (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : A \ B ‚äÜ C) : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C := by
  fix x : U
  assume h2 : x ‚àà A
  define
  or_right with h3


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A \ B ‚äÜ C
x : U
h2 : x ‚àà A
h3 : ¬¨x ‚àà B
‚ä¢ x ‚àà C


We can now complete the proof. h1 _ will be a proof of the goal x ‚àà C, if we can fill in the blank with a proof of x ‚àà A \ B. Since x ‚àà A \ B means x ‚àà A ‚àß ¬¨x ‚àà B, we can prove it with the expression And.intro h2 h3.


example (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : A \ B ‚äÜ C) : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C := by
  fix x : U
  assume h2 : x ‚àà A
  define
  or_right with h3
  show x ‚àà C from h1 (And.intro h2 h3)


>>Goals accomplished üéâ


The fact that P ‚à® Q is equivalent to both ¬¨P ‚Üí Q and ¬¨Q ‚Üí P also suggests another strategy for using a given that is a disjunction.


To use a given of the form P ‚à® Q:

If you are also given ¬¨P, or you can prove that P is false, then you can use this given to conclude that Q is true. Similarly, if you are given ¬¨Q or can prove that Q is false, then you can conclude that P is true.

This strategy is a rule of inference called disjunctive syllogism, and the tactic for using this strategy in Lean is called disj_syll. If you have h1 : P ‚à® Q and h2 : ¬¨P, then the tactic disj_syll h1 h2 will change h1 to h1 : Q; if instead you have h2 : ¬¨Q, then disj_syll h1 h2 will change h1 to h1 : P. Notice that, as with the by_cases tactic, the given h1 gets replaced with the conclusion of the rule. The tactic disj_syll h1 h2 with h3 will preserve the original h1 and introduce the conclusion as a new given with the identifier h3. Also, as with the by_cases tactic, either h1 or h2 can be a complex proof rather than simply an identifier (although in that case it must be enclosed in parentheses, so that Lean can tell where h1 ends and h2 begins). The only requirement is that h1 must be a proof of a disjunction, and h2 must be a proof of the negation of one side of the disjunction. If h1 is not simply an identifier, then you will want to use with to specify the identifier to be used for the conclusion of the rule.
Here‚Äôs an example illustrating the use of the disjunctive syllogism rule.


example
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C
h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B
‚ä¢ A ‚äÜ C


Of course, we begin by introducing an arbitrary element of A. We also rewrite h2 as an equivalent positive statement.


example
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by
  fix a : U
  assume h3 : a ‚àà A
  quant_neg at h2


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C
h2 : ‚àÄ (x : U),
>>  ¬¨x ‚àà A ‚à© B
a : U
h3 : a ‚àà A
‚ä¢ a ‚àà C


We can now make two inferences by combining h1 with h3 and by applying h2 to a. To see how to use the inferred statements, we write out their definitions, and since one of them is a negative statement, we reexpress it as an equivalent positive statement.


example
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by
  fix a : U
  assume h3 : a ‚àà A
  quant_neg at h2
  have h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à™ C := h1 h3
  have h5 : a ‚àâ A ‚à© B := h2 a
  define at h4
  define at h5; demorgan at h5


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C
h2 : ‚àÄ (x : U),
>>  ¬¨x ‚àà A ‚à© B
a : U
h3 : a ‚àà A
h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à® a ‚àà C
h5 : ¬¨a ‚àà A ‚à® ¬¨a ‚àà B
‚ä¢ a ‚àà C


Both h4 and h5 are disjunctions, and looking at h3 we see that the disjunctive syllogism rule can be applied. From h3 and h5 we can draw the conclusion ¬¨a ‚àà B, and then combining that conclusion with h4 we can infer a ‚àà C. Since that is the goal, we are done.


example
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by
  fix a : U
  assume h3 : a ‚àà A
  quant_neg at h2
  have h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à™ C := h1 h3
  have h5 : a ‚àâ A ‚à© B := h2 a
  define at h4
  define at h5; demorgan at h5
  disj_syll h5 h3  --Now h5 : ¬¨a ‚àà B
  disj_syll h4 h5  --Now h4 : a ‚àà C
  show a ‚àà C from h4


>>Goals accomplished üéâ


We‚Äôre going to redo the last example, to illustrate another useful technique in Lean. We start with some of the same steps as before.


example
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by
  fix a : U
  assume h3 : a ‚àà A
  have h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à™ C := h1 h3
  define at h4


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C
h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B
a : U
h3 : a ‚àà A
h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à® a ‚àà C
‚ä¢ a ‚àà C


At this point, you might see a possible route to the goal: from h2 and h3 we should be able to prove that a ‚àâ B, and then, combining that with h4 by the disjunctive syllogism rule, we should be able to deduce the goal a ‚àà C. Let‚Äôs try writing the proof that way.


??example::
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by
  fix a : U
  assume h3 : a ‚àà A
  have h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à™ C := h1 h3
  define at h4
  have h5 : a ‚àâ B := sorry
  disj_syll h4 h5  --Now h4 : a ‚àà C
  show a ‚àà C from h4


>>Goals accomplished üéâ


We have introduced a new idea in this proof. The justification we have given for introducing h5 : a ‚àâ B is sorry. You might think of this as meaning ‚ÄúSorry, I‚Äôm not going to give a justification for this statement, but please accept it anyway.‚Äù Of course, this is cheating; in a complete proof, every step must be justified. Lean accepts sorry as a proof of any statement, but it displays it in red to warn you that you‚Äôre cheating. It also puts a brown squiggle under the keyword example and it puts the message declaration uses 'sorry' in the Infoview, to warn you that, although the proof has reached the goal, it is not fully justified.
Although writing the proof this way is cheating, it is a convenient way to see that our plan of attack for this proof is reasonable. Lean has accepted the proof, except for the warning that we have used sorry. So now we know that if we go back and replace sorry with a proof of a ‚àâ B, then we will have a complete proof.
The proof of a ‚àâ B is hard enough that it is easier to do it in tactic mode rather than term mode. So we will begin the proof as we always do for tactic-mode proofs: we replace sorry with by, leave a blank line, and then put done, indented further than the surrounding text. When we put the cursor on the blank line before done, we see the tactic state for our ‚Äúproof within a proof.‚Äù


example
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by
  fix a : U
  assume h3 : a ‚àà A
  have h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à™ C := h1 h3
  define at h4
  have h5 : a ‚àâ B := by

    **done::
  disj_syll h4 h5  --Now h4 : a ‚àà C
  show a ‚àà C from h4


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C
h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B
a : U
h3 : a ‚àà A
h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à® a ‚àà C
‚ä¢ ¬¨a ‚àà B


Note that h5 : a ‚àâ B is not a given in the tactic state, because we have not yet justified it; in fact, ¬¨a ‚àà B is the goal. This goal is a negative statement, and h2 is also negative. This suggests that we could try using proof by contradiction, achieving the contradiction by contradicting h2. So we use the tactic contradict h2 with h6.


example
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by
  fix a : U
  assume h3 : a ‚àà A
  have h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à™ C := h1 h3
  define at h4
  have h5 : a ‚àâ B := by
    contradict h2 with h6
    **done::
  disj_syll h4 h5  --Now h4 : a ‚àà C
  show a ‚àà C from h4


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C
h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B
a : U
h3 : a ‚àà A
h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à® a ‚àà C
h6 : a ‚àà B
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B


Looking at h3 and h6, we see that the right value to plug in for x in the goal is a. In fact, Exists.intro a _ will prove the goal, if we can fill in the blank with a proof of a ‚àà A ‚à© B. Since this means a ‚àà A ‚àß a ‚àà B, we can prove it with And.intro h3 h6. Thus, we can complete the proof in one more step:


example
    (U : Type) (A B C : Set U) (h1 : A ‚äÜ B ‚à™ C)
    (h2 : ¬¨‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B) : A ‚äÜ C := by
  fix a : U
  assume h3 : a ‚àà A
  have h4 : a ‚àà B ‚à™ C := h1 h3
  define at h4
  have h5 : a ‚àâ B := by
    contradict h2 with h6
    show ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B from
      Exists.intro a (And.intro h3 h6)
    done
  disj_syll h4 h5  --Now h4 : a ‚àà C
  show a ‚àà C from h4


>>Goals accomplished üéâ


The red squiggle has disappeared from the word done, indicating that the proof is complete.
It was not really necessary for us to use sorry when writing this proof. We could have simply written the steps in order, exactly as they appear above. Any time you use the have tactic with a conclusion that is difficult to justify, you have a choice. You can establish the have with sorry, complete the proof, and then return and fill in a justification for the have, as we did in the example above. Or, you can justify the have right away by typing by after := and then plunging into the ‚Äúproof within in a proof.‚Äù Once you complete the inner proof, you can continue with the original proof.
And in case you were wondering: yes, if the inner proof uses the have tactic with a statement that is hard to justify, then you can write a ‚Äúproof within a proof within a proof‚Äù!

title: 3¬† Proofs
text:
3.6. Existence and Uniqueness Proofs
Recall that ‚àÉ! (x : U), P x means that there is exactly one x of type U such that P x is true. One way to deal with a given or goal of this form is to use the define tactic to rewrite it as the equivalent statement ‚àÉ (x : U), P x ‚àß ‚àÄ (x_1 : U), P x_1 ‚Üí x_1 = x. You can then apply techniques discussed previously in this chapter. However, there are also proof techniques, and corresponding Lean tactics, for working directly with givens and goals of this form.
Often a goal of the form ‚àÉ! (x : U), P x is proven by using the following strategy. This is a slight rephrasing of the strategy presented in HTPI. The rephrasing is based on the fact that for any propositions A, B, and C, A ‚àß B ‚Üí C is equivalent to A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C (you can check this equivalence by making a truth table). The second of these statements is usually easier to work with in Lean than the first one, so we will often rephrase statements that have the form A ‚àß B ‚Üí C as A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C. That‚Äôs what we have done here, as you will see if you compare the strategy stated below to the one in HTPI.

To prove a goal of the form ‚àÉ! (x : U), P x:

Prove ‚àÉ (x : U), P x and ‚àÄ (x_1 x_2 : U), P x_1 ‚Üí P x_2 ‚Üí x_1 = x_2. The first of these goals says that there exists an x such that P x is true, and the second says that it is unique. The two parts of the proof are therefore sometimes labeled existence and uniqueness.

To apply this strategy in a Lean proof, we use the tactic exists_unique. We‚Äôll illustrate this with the theorem from Example 3.6.2 in HTPI. Here‚Äôs how that theorem and its proof are presented in HTPI:

There is a unique set \(A\) such that for every set \(B\), \(A \cup B = B\).


Proof. Existence: Clearly \(\forall B(\varnothing \cup B = B)\), so \(\varnothing\) has the required property.
Uniqueness: Suppose \(\forall B(C \cup B = B)\) and \(\forall B(D \cup B = B)\). Applying the first of these assumptions to \(D\) we see that \(C \cup D = D\), and applying the second to \(C\) we get \(D \cup C = C\). But clearly \(C \cup D = D \cup C\), so \(C = D\). ¬†‚ñ°

You will notice that there are two statements in this proof that are described as ‚Äúclearly‚Äù true. This brings up one of the difficulties with proving theorems in Lean: things that are clear to us are not necessarily clear to Lean! There are two ways to deal with such ‚Äúclear‚Äù statements. The first is to see if the statement is in the library of theorems that Lean knows. The second is to prove the statement as a preliminary theorem that can then be used in the proof of our main theorem. We‚Äôll take the second approach here, since proving these ‚Äúclear‚Äù facts will give us more practice with Lean proofs, but later we‚Äôll have more to say about searching for statements in Lean‚Äôs theorem library.
The first theorem we need says that for every set B, ‚àÖ ‚à™ B = B, and it brings up a subtle issue: in Lean, the symbol ‚àÖ is ambiguous! The reason for this is Lean‚Äôs strict typing rules. For each type U, there is an empty set of type Set U. There is, for example, the set of type Set Nat that contains no natural numbers, and also the set of type Set Real that contains no real numbers. To Lean, these are different sets, because they have different types. Which one does the symbol ‚àÖ denote? The answer will be different in different contexts. Lean can sometimes figure out from context which empty set you have in mind, but if it can‚Äôt, then you have to tell it explicitly by writing (‚àÖ : Set U) rather than ‚àÖ.
With that preparation, we are ready to prove our first preliminary theorem. To avoid problems with ambiguity, we‚Äôll tell Lean explicitly which empty set we have in mind in this theorem. Since the goal is an equation between sets, our first step is to use the tactic apply Set.ext.


theorem empty_union {U : Type} (B : Set U) :
    (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B = B := by
  apply Set.ext


case h
U : Type
B : Set U
‚ä¢ ‚àÄ (x : U),
>>  x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à™ B ‚Üî x ‚àà B


Based on the form of the goal, our next two tactics should be fix x : U and apply Iff.intro. This leaves us with two goals, corresponding to the two directions of the biconditional, but we‚Äôll focus first on just the left-to-right direction.


theorem empty_union {U : Type} (B : Set U) :
    (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B = B := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  apply Iff.intro


case h.mp
U : Type
B : Set U
x : U
‚ä¢ x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à™ B ‚Üí x ‚àà B


Of course, our next step is to assume x ‚àà (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B. To help us see how to move forward, we also write out the definition of this assumption.


theorem empty_union {U : Type} (B : Set U) :
    (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B = B := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : x ‚àà (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B
  define at h1


case h.mp
U : Type
B : Set U
x : U
h1 : x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à® x ‚àà B
‚ä¢ x ‚àà B


Now you should see a way to complete the proof: the statement x ‚àà ‚àÖ is false, so we should be able to apply the disjunctive syllogism rule to h1 to infer the goal x ‚àà B. To carry out this plan, we‚Äôll first have to prove x ‚àâ (‚àÖ : Set U). We‚Äôll use the have tactic, and since there‚Äôs no obvious term-mode proof to justify it, we‚Äôll try a tactic-mode proof.


theorem empty_union {U : Type} (B : Set U) :
    (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B = B := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : x ‚àà (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B
  define at h1
  have h2 : x ‚àâ (‚àÖ : Set U) := by

    **done::


U : Type
B : Set U
x : U
h1 : x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à® x ‚àà B
‚ä¢ ¬¨x ‚àà ‚àÖ


The goal for our ‚Äúproof within a proof‚Äù is a negative statement, so proof by contradiction seems like a good start.


theorem empty_union {U : Type} (B : Set U) :
    (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B = B := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : x ‚àà (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B
  define at h1
  have h2 : x ‚àâ (‚àÖ : Set U) := by
    by_contra h3
    **done::


U : Type
B : Set U
x : U
h1 : x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à® x ‚àà B
h3 : x ‚àà ‚àÖ
‚ä¢ False


To see how to use the new assumption h3, we use the tactic define at h3. The definition Lean gives for the statement x ‚àà ‚àÖ is False. In other words, Lean knows that, by the definition of ‚àÖ, the statement x ‚àà ‚àÖ is false. Since False is our goal, this completes the inner proof, and we can return to the main proof.


theorem empty_union {U : Type} (B : Set U) :
    (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B = B := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : x ‚àà (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B
  define at h1
  have h2 : x ‚àâ (‚àÖ : Set U) := by
    by_contra h3
    define at h3  --Now h3 : False
    show False from h3
    done


case h.mp
U : Type
B : Set U
x : U
h1 : x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à® x ‚àà B
h2 : ¬¨x ‚àà ‚àÖ
‚ä¢ x ‚àà B


Now that we have established the claim h2 : ¬¨x ‚àà ‚àÖ, we can apply the disjunctive syllogism rule to h1 and h2 to reach the goal. This completes the left-to-right direction of the biconditional proof, so we move on to the right-to-left direction.


theorem empty_union {U : Type} (B : Set U) :
    (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B = B := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : x ‚àà (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B
  define at h1
  have h2 : x ‚àâ (‚àÖ : Set U) := by
    by_contra h3
    define at h3  --Now h3 : False
    show False from h3
    done
  disj_syll h1 h2  --Now h1 : x ‚àà B
  show x ‚àà B from h1
  -- (‚Üê)


case h.mpr
U : Type
B : Set U
x : U
‚ä¢ x ‚àà B ‚Üí x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à™ B


This direction of the biconditional proof is easier: once we introduce the assumption h1 : x ‚àà B, our goal will be x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à™ B, which means x ‚àà ‚àÖ ‚à® x ‚àà B, and we can prove it with the proof Or.inr h1.


theorem empty_union {U : Type} (B : Set U) :
    (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B = B := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : x ‚àà (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B
  define at h1
  have h2 : x ‚àâ (‚àÖ : Set U) := by
    by_contra h3
    define at h3  --Now h3 : False
    show False from h3
    done
  disj_syll h1 h2  --Now h1 : x ‚àà B
  show x ‚àà B from h1
  -- (‚Üê)
  assume h1 : x ‚àà B
  show x ‚àà (‚àÖ : Set U) ‚à™ B from Or.inr h1


>>Goals accomplished üéâ


The second fact that was called ‚Äúclear‚Äù in the proof from Example 3.6.2 was the equation C ‚à™ D = D ‚à™ C. This looks like an instance of the commutativity of the union operator. Let‚Äôs prove that union is commutative.


theorem union_comm {U : Type} (X Y : Set U) :
    X ‚à™ Y = Y ‚à™ X := by


U : Type
X Y : Set U
‚ä¢ X ‚à™ Y = Y ‚à™ X


Once again, we begin with apply Set.ext, which converts the goal to ‚àÄ (x : U), x ‚àà X ‚à™ Y ‚ÜîÔ∏é x ‚àà Y ‚à™ X, and then fix x : U.


theorem union_comm {U : Type} (X Y : Set U) :
    X ‚à™ Y = Y ‚à™ X := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U


case h
U : Type
X Y : Set U
x : U
‚ä¢ x ‚àà X ‚à™ Y ‚Üî x ‚àà Y ‚à™ X


By the definition of union, our current goal means x ‚àà X ‚à® x ‚àà Y ‚ÜîÔ∏é x ‚àà Y ‚à® x ‚àà X. You could prove this by a somewhat tedious application of the rules for biconditionals and disjunctions that were discussed in the last two sections, and we invite you to try it. But there is another possibility. The goal now has the form P ‚à® Q ‚ÜîÔ∏é Q ‚à® P, which is the commutative law for ‚Äúor‚Äù (see Section 1.2 of HTPI). We saw in a previous example that Lean has, in its library, the associative law for ‚Äúand‚Äù; it is called and_assoc. Does Lean also know the commutative law for ‚Äúor‚Äù?
Try typing #check @or_ in VS Code. As soon as you type this, a pop-up window appears with possible completions of this command. You will see or_assoc on the list, as well as or_comm. Select or_comm, and you‚Äôll get this response: @or_comm : ‚àÄ {a b : Prop}, a ‚à® b ‚ÜîÔ∏é b ‚à® a. Since a and b are implicit arguments in this theorem, you can use or_comm to prove any statement of the form a ‚à® b ‚ÜîÔ∏é b ‚à® a, where Lean will figure out for itself what a and b stand for. In particular, or_comm will prove our current goal.


theorem union_comm {U : Type} (X Y : Set U) :
    X ‚à™ Y = Y ‚à™ X := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  show x ‚àà X ‚à™ Y ‚Üî x ‚àà Y ‚à™ X from or_comm


>>Goals accomplished üéâ


We have now proven the two statements that were said to be ‚Äúclearly‚Äù true in the proof in Example 3.6.2 of HTPI, and we have given them names. As with any theorem in Lean‚Äôs library, you can use the #check command to confirm what these theorems say. If you type #check @empty_union and #check @union_comm, you will get these results:

@empty_union : ‚àÄ {U : Type} (B : Set U), ‚àÖ ‚à™ B = B @union_comm : ‚àÄ {U : Type} (X Y : Set U), X ‚à™ Y = Y ‚à™ X

Notice that Lean has applied a universal quantifier to the variables that were declared at the beginnings of the two theorems. When you declare variables in the statement of a theorem, it is understood that they can stand for anything of the appropriate type, so Lean treats them as implicitly universally quantified (see Section 3.1 of HTPI). Also, we used curly braces when we introduced the type U, so it is an implicit argument in both theorems and will not need to be specified when we apply the theorems.
We are finally ready to prove the theorem from Example 3.6.2. Here is the theorem:


theorem Example_3_6_2 (U : Type) :
    ‚àÉ! (A : Set U), ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
    A ‚à™ B = B := by


U : Type
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ! A, ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>  A ‚à™ B = B


The goal starts with ‚àÉ!, so we use our new tactic, exists_unique.


theorem Example_3_6_2 (U : Type) :
    ‚àÉ! (A : Set U), ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
    A ‚à™ B = B := by
  exists_unique


case Existence
U : Type
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ A, ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>  A ‚à™ B = B
case Uniqueness
U : Type
‚ä¢ ‚àÄ (A_1 A_2 : Set U),
>>  (‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>      A_1 ‚à™ B = B) ‚Üí
>>  (‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>      A_2 ‚à™ B = B) ‚Üí
>>  A_1 = A_2


We have two goals, labeled Existence and Uniqueness. Imitating the proof from HTPI, we prove existence by using the value ‚àÖ for A. It turns out that in this context, Lean is able to figure out which empty set we mean by ‚àÖ, so we don‚Äôt need to specify the type.


theorem Example_3_6_2 (U : Type) :
    ‚àÉ! (A : Set U), ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
    A ‚à™ B = B := by
  exists_unique
  -- Existence
  apply Exists.intro ‚àÖ


case Existence
U : Type
‚ä¢ ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>  ‚àÖ ‚à™ B = B


The goal is now precisely the statement of the theorem empty_union, so we can prove it by simply citing that theorem.


theorem Example_3_6_2 (U : Type) :
    ‚àÉ! (A : Set U), ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
    A ‚à™ B = B := by
  exists_unique
  -- Existence
  apply Exists.intro ‚àÖ
  show ‚àÄ (B : Set U), ‚àÖ ‚à™ B = B from empty_union
  -- Uniqueness


case Uniqueness
U : Type
‚ä¢ ‚àÄ (A_1 A_2 : Set U),
>>  (‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>      A_1 ‚à™ B = B) ‚Üí
>>  (‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>      A_2 ‚à™ B = B) ‚Üí
>>  A_1 = A_2


For the uniqueness proof, we begin by introducing arbitrary sets C and D and assuming ‚àÄ (B : Set U), C ‚à™ B = B and ‚àÄ (B : Set U), D ‚à™ B = B, exactly as in the HTPI proof.


theorem Example_3_6_2 (U : Type) :
    ‚àÉ! (A : Set U), ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
    A ‚à™ B = B := by
  exists_unique
  -- Existence
  apply Exists.intro ‚àÖ
  show ‚àÄ (B : Set U), ‚àÖ ‚à™ B = B from empty_union
  -- Uniqueness
  fix C : Set U; fix D : Set U
  assume h1 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U), C ‚à™ B = B
  assume h2 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U), D ‚à™ B = B


case Uniqueness
U : Type
C D : Set U
h1 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>  C ‚à™ B = B
h2 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>  D ‚à™ B = B
‚ä¢ C = D


The next step in HTPI was to apply h1 to D, and h2 to C. We do the same thing in Lean.


theorem Example_3_6_2 (U : Type) :
    ‚àÉ! (A : Set U), ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
    A ‚à™ B = B := by
  exists_unique
  -- Existence
  apply Exists.intro ‚àÖ
  show ‚àÄ (B : Set U), ‚àÖ ‚à™ B = B from empty_union
  -- Uniqueness
  fix C : Set U; fix D : Set U
  assume h1 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U), C ‚à™ B = B
  assume h2 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U), D ‚à™ B = B
  have h3 : C ‚à™ D = D := h1 D
  have h4 : D ‚à™ C = C := h2 C


case Uniqueness
U : Type
C D : Set U
h1 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>  C ‚à™ B = B
h2 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
>>  D ‚à™ B = B
h3 : C ‚à™ D = D
h4 : D ‚à™ C = C
‚ä¢ C = D


The goal can now be achieved by stringing together a sequence of equations: C = D ‚à™ C = C ‚à™ D = D. The first of these equations is h4.symm‚Äîthat is, h4 read backwards; the second follows from the commutative law for union; and the third is h3. We saw in Section 3.4 that you can prove a biconditional statement in Lean by stringing together a sequence of biconditionals in a calculational proof. Exactly the same method applies to equations. Here is the complete proof of the theorem:
theorem Example_3_6_2 (U : Type) :
    ‚àÉ! (A : Set U), ‚àÄ (B : Set U),
    A ‚à™ B = B := by
  exists_unique
  -- Existence
  apply Exists.intro ‚àÖ
  show ‚àÄ (B : Set U), ‚àÖ ‚à™ B = B from empty_union
  -- Uniqueness
  fix C : Set U; fix D : Set U
  assume h1 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U), C ‚à™ B = B
  assume h2 : ‚àÄ (B : Set U), D ‚à™ B = B
  have h3 : C ‚à™ D = D := h1 D
  have h4 : D ‚à™ C = C := h2 C
  show C = D from
    calc
      C = D ‚à™ C := h4.symm
      _ = C ‚à™ D := union_comm D C
      _ = D     := h3
Since the statement ‚àÉ! (x : U), P x asserts both the existence and the uniqueness of an object satisfying the predicate P, we have the following strategy for using a given of this form:


To use a given of the form ‚àÉ! (x : U), P x:

Introduce a new variable, say a, into the proof to stand for an object of type U for which P a is true. You may also assert that ‚àÄ (x_1 x_2 : U), P x_1 ‚Üí P x_2 ‚Üí x_1 = x2.

If you have a given h : ‚àÉ! (x : U), P x, then the tactic obtain (a : U) (h1 : P a) (h2 : ‚àÄ (x_1 x_2 : U), P x_1 ‚Üí P x_2 ‚Üí x_1 = x_2) from h will introduce into the tactic state a new variable a of type U and new givens (h1 : P a) and (h2 : ‚àÄ (x_1 x_2 : U), P x_1 ‚Üí P x_2 ‚Üí x_1 = x_2). To illustrate the use of this tactic, let‚Äôs prove the theorem in Example 3.6.4 of HTPI.


theorem Example_3_6_4 (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B)
    (h2 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© C)
    (h3 : ‚àÉ! (x : U), x ‚àà A) :
    ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà B ‚à© C := by


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B
h2 : ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© C
h3 : ‚àÉ! x, x ‚àà A
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà B ‚à© C


We begin by applying the obtain tactic to h1, h2, and h3. In the case of h3, we get an extra given asserting the uniqueness of the element of A. We also write out the definitions of two of the new givens we obtain.


theorem Example_3_6_4 (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B)
    (h2 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© C)
    (h3 : ‚àÉ! (x : U), x ‚àà A) :
    ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà B ‚à© C := by
  obtain (b : U) (h4 : b ‚àà A ‚à© B) from h1
  obtain (c : U) (h5 : c ‚àà A ‚à© C) from h2
  obtain (a : U) (h6 : a ‚àà A) (h7 : ‚àÄ (y z : U),
    y ‚àà A ‚Üí z ‚àà A ‚Üí y = z)  from h3
  define at h4; define at h5


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B
h2 : ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© C
h3 : ‚àÉ! x, x ‚àà A
b : U
h4 : b ‚àà A ‚àß b ‚àà B
c : U
h5 : c ‚àà A ‚àß c ‚àà C
a : U
h6 : a ‚àà A
h7 : ‚àÄ (y z : U),
>>  y ‚àà A ‚Üí z ‚àà A ‚Üí y = z
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà B ‚à© C


The key to the rest of the proof is the observation that, by the uniqueness of the element of A, b must be equal to c. To justify this conclusion, note that by two applications of universal instantiation, h7 b c is a proof of b ‚àà A ‚Üí c ‚àà A ‚Üí b = c, and therefore by two applications of modus ponens, h7 b c h4.left h5.left is a proof of b = c.


theorem Example_3_6_4 (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B)
    (h2 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© C)
    (h3 : ‚àÉ! (x : U), x ‚àà A) :
    ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà B ‚à© C := by
  obtain (b : U) (h4 : b ‚àà A ‚à© B) from h1
  obtain (c : U) (h5 : c ‚àà A ‚à© C) from h2
  obtain (a : U) (h6 : a ‚àà A) (h7 : ‚àÄ (y z : U),
    y ‚àà A ‚Üí z ‚àà A ‚Üí y = z)  from h3
  define at h4; define at h5
  have h8 : b = c := h7 b c h4.left h5.left


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B
h2 : ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© C
h3 : ‚àÉ! x, x ‚àà A
b : U
h4 : b ‚àà A ‚àß b ‚àà B
c : U
h5 : c ‚àà A ‚àß c ‚àà C
a : U
h6 : a ‚àà A
h7 : ‚àÄ (y z : U),
>>  y ‚àà A ‚Üí z ‚àà A ‚Üí y = z
h8 : b = c
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà B ‚à© C


For our next step, we will need a new tactic. Since we have h8 : b = c, we should be able to replace b with c anywhere it appears. The tactic that allows us to do this called rewrite. If h is a proof of any equation s = t, then rewrite [h] will replace all occurrences of s in the goal with t. Notice that it is the left-hand side of the equation that is replaced with the right-hand side; if you want the replacement to go in the other direction, so that t is replaced with s, you can use rewrite [‚Üêh]. (Alternatively, since h.symm is a proof of t = s, you can use rewrite [h.symm].) You can also apply the rewrite tactic to biconditional statements. If you have h : P ‚ÜîÔ∏é Q, then rewrite [h] will cause all occurrences of P in the goal to be replaced with Q (and rewrite [‚Üêh] will replace Q with P).
As with many other tactics, you can add at h' to specify that the replacement should be done in the given h' rather than the goal. In our case, rewrite [h8] at h4 will change both occurrences of b in h4 to c.


theorem Example_3_6_4 (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B)
    (h2 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© C)
    (h3 : ‚àÉ! (x : U), x ‚àà A) :
    ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà B ‚à© C := by
  obtain (b : U) (h4 : b ‚àà A ‚à© B) from h1
  obtain (c : U) (h5 : c ‚àà A ‚à© C) from h2
  obtain (a : U) (h6 : a ‚àà A) (h7 : ‚àÄ (y z : U),
    y ‚àà A ‚Üí z ‚àà A ‚Üí y = z)  from h3
  define at h4; define at h5
  have h8 : b = c := h7 b c h4.left h5.left
  rewrite [h8] at h4


U : Type
A B C : Set U
h1 : ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© B
h2 : ‚àÉ x, x ‚àà A ‚à© C
h3 : ‚àÉ! x, x ‚àà A
b c : U
h4 : c ‚àà A ‚àß c ‚àà B
h5 : c ‚àà A ‚àß c ‚àà C

Now the right-hand sides of h4 and h5 tell us that we can prove the goal by plugging in c for x. Here is the complete proof:
theorem Example_3_6_4 (U : Type) (A B C : Set U)
    (h1 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© B)
    (h2 : ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà A ‚à© C)
    (h3 : ‚àÉ! (x : U), x ‚àà A) :
    ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà B ‚à© C := by
  obtain (b : U) (h4 : b ‚àà A ‚à© B) from h1
  obtain (c : U) (h5 : c ‚àà A ‚à© C) from h2
  obtain (a : U) (h6 : a ‚àà A) (h7 : ‚àÄ (y z : U),
    y ‚àà A ‚Üí z ‚àà A ‚Üí y = z)  from h3
  define at h4; define at h5
  have h8 : b = c := h7 b c h4.left h5.left
  rewrite [h8] at h4
  show ‚àÉ (x : U), x ‚àà B ‚à© C from
    Exists.intro c (And.intro h4.right h5.right)
You might want to compare the Lean proof above to the proof of this theorem as it appears in HTPI:

Suppose \(A\), \(B\), and \(C\) are sets, \(A\) and \(B\) are not disjoint, \(A\) and \(C\) are not disjoint, and \(A\) has exactly one element. Then \(B\) and \(C\) are not disjoint


Proof. Since \(A\) and \(B\) are not disjoint, we can let \(b\) be something such that \(b \in A\) and \(b \in B\). Similarly, since \(A\) and \(C\) are not disjoint, there is some object \(c\) such that \(c \in A\) and \(c \in C\). Since \(A\) has only one element, we must have \(b = c\). Thus \(b = c \in B \cap C\) and therefore \(B\) and \(C\) are not disjoint. ¬†‚ñ°

Before ending this section, we return to the question of how you can tell if a theorem you want to use is in Lean‚Äôs library. In an earlier example, we guessed that the commutative law for ‚Äúor‚Äù might be in Lean‚Äôs library, and we were then able to use the #check command to confirm it. But there is another technique that we could have used: the tactic library_search. Let‚Äôs return to our proof of the theorem union_comm, which started like this:


theorem union_comm {U : Type} (X Y : Set U) :
    X ‚à™ Y = Y ‚à™ X := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U


case h
U : Type
X Y : Set U
x : U
‚ä¢ x ‚àà X ‚à™ Y ‚Üî x ‚àà Y ‚à™ X


To make the goal easier for the library_search tactic to recognize, we‚Äôll write out the definitions of the two sides of the biconditional. We use a variant of the define tactic that allows us to write out the definition of just a part of a given or the goal. The tactic define : x ‚àà X ‚à™ Y will replace x ‚àà X ‚à™ Y with its definition wherever it appears in the goal, and then define : x ‚àà Y ‚à™ X will replace x ‚àà Y ‚à™ X with its definition. (As usual, you can add at to do the replacements in a given rather than the goal.)


theorem union_comm {U : Type} (X Y : Set U) :
    X ‚à™ Y = Y ‚à™ X := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  define : x ‚àà X ‚à™ Y
  define : x ‚àà Y ‚à™ X


case h
U : Type
X Y : Set U
x : U
‚ä¢ x ‚àà X ‚à® x ‚àà Y ‚Üî
>>  x ‚àà Y ‚à® x ‚àà X


We have done these steps to give the library_search tactic the best chance of recognizing the goal as the commutative law for ‚Äúor‚Äù. Let‚Äôs give it a try.
theorem union_comm {U : Type} (X Y : Set U) :
    X ‚à™ Y = Y ‚à™ X := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix x : U
  define : x ‚àà X ‚à™ Y
  define : x ‚àà Y ‚à™ X
  ##library_search::
The blue squiggle indicates that the library_search tactic has produced an answer, which you will find in the Infoview pane: exact or_comm' (x ‚àà X) (x ‚àà Y). The word exact is the name of a tactic that we have not discussed; it is a shorthand for show _ from, where the blank gets filled in with the goal. Thus, you can think of library_search‚Äôs answer as a shortened form of the tactic

show x ‚àà X ‚à® x ‚àà Y ‚ÜîÔ∏é x ‚àà Y ‚à® x ‚àà X from or_comm' (x ‚àà X) (x ‚àà Y).

Usually your proof will be more readable if you use the show tactic to state explicitly the goal that is being proven. This also gives Lean a chance to correct you if you have become confused about what goal you are proving. But sometimes‚Äîfor example, if the goal is very long‚Äîit is convenient to use the exact tactic instead. You might think of exact as meaning ‚Äúthe following is a term-mode proof that is exactly what is needed to prove the goal.‚Äù
The library_search tactic has not only come up with a suggested tactic, it has applied that tactic, and the proof is now complete. You can confirm that the tactic completes the proof by replacing the line library_search in the proof with either library_search‚Äôs suggested exact tactic or the show tactic displayed above.
But what is or_comm'? The command #check or_comm' gives the result

or_comm' : ‚àÄ (a b : Prop), a ‚à® b ‚ÜîÔ∏é b ‚à® a.

So or_comm' is the same as or_comm, except that the arguments a and b are not implicit; that‚Äôs why library_search had to specify values for those arguments in its answer. The #check command also produces a suggestion that we should use or_comm instead.
The library_search tactic is somewhat unpredictable; sometimes it is able to find the right theorem in the library, and sometimes it isn‚Äôt. But it is always worth a try. Other tactics that may be helpful are suggest and hint.

title: 3¬† Proofs
text:
3.7. More Examples of Proofs
It is finally time to discuss proofs involving algebraic reasoning. Lean has types for several different kinds of numbers. Nat is the type of natural numbers‚Äîthat is, the numbers 0, 1, 2, ‚Ä¶. Int is the type of integers, Rat is the type of rational numbers, Real is the type of real numbers, and Complex is the type of complex numbers. Lean also uses the notation ‚Ñï, ‚Ñ§, ‚Ñö, ‚Ñù, and ‚ÑÇ for these types. To write formulas involving arithmetic operations, you should use the symbols + for addition, - for subtraction, * for multiplication, / for division, and ^ for exponentiation. To see what‚Äôs involved in proving theorems about numbers in Lean, we‚Äôll turn to a few examples from earlier in Chapter 3 of HTPI.
We begin with Theorem 3.3.7, which concerns divisibility of integers. As in HTPI, for integers x and y, we will write x ‚à£ y to mean that x divides y, or y is divisible by x. The formal definition is that x ‚à£ y means that there is an integer k such that y = x * k. For example, 3 ‚à£ 12, since 12 = 3 * 4. Lean knows this notation, but there is an important warning: to type the vertical line that means ‚Äúdivides,‚Äù you must type \|, not simply |. (There are two slightly different vertical line symbols, and you have to look closely to see that they are different: | and ‚à£. It is the second one that means ‚Äúdivides‚Äù in Lean, and to enter it you must type \|.) Here is Theorem 3.3.7, written using our usual rephrasing of a statement of the form A ‚àß B ‚Üí C as A ‚Üí B ‚Üí C.


theorem Theorem_3_3_7 :
    ‚àÄ (a b c : Int), a ‚à£ b ‚Üí b ‚à£ c ‚Üí a ‚à£ c := by


‚ä¢ ‚àÄ (a b c : ‚Ñ§),
>>  a ‚à£ b ‚Üí b ‚à£ c ‚Üí a ‚à£ c


Of course, we begin the proof by introducing arbitrary integers a, b, and c, and assuming a ‚à£ b and b ‚à£ c. We also write out the definitions of our assumptions and the goal.


theorem Theorem_3_3_7 :
    ‚àÄ (a b c : Int), a ‚à£ b ‚Üí b ‚à£ c ‚Üí a ‚à£ c := by
  fix a : Int; fix b : Int; fix c : Int
  assume h1 : a ‚à£ b; assume h2 : b ‚à£ c
  define at h1; define at h2; define


a b c : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, b = a * c
h2 : ‚àÉ c_1, c = b * c_1
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ c_1, c = a * c_1


We always use existential givens right away, so we use h1 and h2 to introduce two new variables, m and n.


theorem Theorem_3_3_7 :
    ‚àÄ (a b c : Int), a ‚à£ b ‚Üí b ‚à£ c ‚Üí a ‚à£ c := by
  fix a : Int; fix b : Int; fix c : Int
  assume h1 : a ‚à£ b; assume h2 : b ‚à£ c
  define at h1; define at h2; define
  obtain (m : Int) (h3 : b = a * m) from h1
  obtain (n : Int) (h4 : c = b * n) from h2


a b c : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, b = a * c
h2 : ‚àÉ c_1, c = b * c_1
m : ‚Ñ§
h3 : b = a * m
n : ‚Ñ§
h4 : c = b * n
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ c_1, c = a * c_1


If we substitute the value for b given in h3 into h4, we will see how to reach the goal. Of course, the rewrite tactic is what we need for this.


theorem Theorem_3_3_7 :
    ‚àÄ (a b c : Int), a ‚à£ b ‚Üí b ‚à£ c ‚Üí a ‚à£ c := by
  fix a : Int; fix b : Int; fix c : Int
  assume h1 : a ‚à£ b; assume h2 : b ‚à£ c
  define at h1; define at h2; define
  obtain (m : Int) (h3 : b = a * m) from h1
  obtain (n : Int) (h4 : c = b * n) from h2
  rewrite [h3] at h4   --h4: c = a * m * n


a b c : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, b = a * c
h2 : ‚àÉ c_1, c = b * c_1
m : ‚Ñ§
h3 : b = a * m
n : ‚Ñ§
h4 : c = a * m * n
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ c_1, c = a * c_1


Looking at h4, we see that the value we should use for c_1 in the goal is m * n.


theorem Theorem_3_3_7 :
    ‚àÄ (a b c : Int), a ‚à£ b ‚Üí b ‚à£ c ‚Üí a ‚à£ c := by
  fix a : Int; fix b : Int; fix c : Int
  assume h1 : a ‚à£ b; assume h2 : b ‚à£ c
  define at h1; define at h2; define
  obtain (m : Int) (h3 : b = a * m) from h1
  obtain (n : Int) (h4 : c = b * n) from h2
  rewrite [h3] at h4   --h4: c = a * m * n
  apply Exists.intro (m * n)


a b c : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, b = a * c
h2 : ‚àÉ c_1, c = b * c_1
m : ‚Ñ§
h3 : b = a * m
n : ‚Ñ§
h4 : c = a * m * n
‚ä¢ c = a * (m * n)


Comparing h4 to the goal, you might think that we can finish the proof with show c = a * (m * n) from h4. But if you try it, you will get an error message. What‚Äôs the problem? The difference in the parentheses is the clue. Lean groups the arithmetic operations +, -, *, and / to the left, so h4 means h4 : c = (a * m) * n, which is not quite the same as the goal. To prove the goal, we will need to apply the associative law for multiplication.
We have already seen that and_assoc is Lean‚Äôs name for the associative law for ‚Äúand‚Äù. Perhaps you can guess that the name for the associative law for multiplication is mul_assoc. If you type #check mul_assoc, Lean‚Äôs response will be something like:

mul_assoc : ‚àÄ (a b c : ?m.36649), a * b * c = a * (b * c).

The appearance of ?m... here indicates that mul_assoc has implicit arguments. The implicit arguments in this case are a little complicated‚Äîof course, you can see them by typing #check @mul_assoc‚Äîbut what they mean is that mul_assoc can be used to prove any statement of the form ‚àÄ (a b c : U), a * b * c = a * (b * c), as long as U is a type that has an associative multiplication operation. In particular, mul_assoc can be used as a proof of ‚àÄ (a b c : Int), a * b * c = a * (b * c). (There are also versions of this theorem for particular number types. You can use the #check command to verify the theorems Nat.mul_assoc : ‚àÄ (a b c : ‚Ñï), a * b * c = a * (b * c), Int.mul_assoc : ‚àÄ (a b c : ‚Ñ§), a * b * c = a * (b * c), and so on.)
Returning to our proof of Theorem 3.3.7, by three applications of universal instantiation, mul_assoc a m n is a proof of a * m * n = a * (m * n), and that is exactly what we need to finish the proof. The tactic rewrite [mul_assoc a m n] at h4 will replace a * m * n in h4 with a * (m * n).


theorem Theorem_3_3_7 :
    ‚àÄ (a b c : Int), a ‚à£ b ‚Üí b ‚à£ c ‚Üí a ‚à£ c := by
  fix a : Int; fix b : Int; fix c : Int
  assume h1 : a ‚à£ b; assume h2 : b ‚à£ c
  define at h1; define at h2; define
  obtain (m : Int) (h3 : b = a * m) from h1
  obtain (n : Int) (h4 : c = b * n) from h2
  rewrite [h3] at h4   --h4: c = a * m * n
  apply Exists.intro (m * n)
  rewrite [mul_assoc a m n] at h4


a b c : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, b = a * c
h2 : ‚àÉ c_1, c = b * c_1
m : ‚Ñ§
h3 : b = a * m
n : ‚Ñ§
h4 : c = a * (m * n)
‚ä¢ c = a * (m * n)


By the way, this is a case in which Lean could have figured out some details on its own. If we had used rewrite [mul_assoc _ _ _] at h4, then Lean would have figured out that the blanks had to be filled in with a, m, and n. And as with the apply tactic, blanks at the end of rewrite rules can be left out, so even rewrite [mul_assoc] at h4 would have worked.
Of course, now h4 really does match the goal exactly, so we can use it to complete the proof.
theorem Theorem_3_3_7 :
    ‚àÄ (a b c : Int), a ‚à£ b ‚Üí b ‚à£ c ‚Üí a ‚à£ c := by
  fix a : Int; fix b : Int; fix c : Int
  assume h1 : a ‚à£ b; assume h2 : b ‚à£ c
  define at h1; define at h2; define
  obtain (m : Int) (h3 : b = a * m) from h1
  obtain (n : Int) (h4 : c = b * n) from h2
  rewrite [h3] at h4   --h4: c = a * m * n
  apply Exists.intro (m * n)
  rewrite [mul_assoc a m n] at h4
  show c = a * (m * n) from h4
As usual, you might find it instructive to compare the Lean proof above to the proof of this theorem in HTPI.
For our next example, we‚Äôll do a somewhat more complex proof concerning divisibility. Here is the proof from HTPI.

For every integer \(n\), \(6 \mid n\) iff \(2 \mid n\) and \(3 \mid n\).


Proof. Let \(n\) be an arbitrary integer.
(\(\to\)) Suppose \(6 \mid n\). Then we can choose an integer \(k\) such that \(6k=n\). Therefore \(n = 6k = 2(3k)\), so \(2 \mid n\), and similarly \(n = 6k = 3(2k)\), so \(3 \mid n\).
(\(\leftarrow\)) Suppose \(2 \mid n\) and \(3 \mid n\). Then we can choose integers \(j\) and \(k\) such that \(n = 2j\) and \(n = 3k\). Therefore \(6(j-k) = 6j - 6k = 3(2j) - 2(3k) = 3n - 2n = n\), so \(6 \mid n\). ¬†‚ñ°

Let‚Äôs try writing the proof in Lean. We use exactly the same strategy as in the HTPI proof: we begin by fixing an arbitrary integer n, and then we prove the two directions of the biconditional separately.


theorem Theorem_3_4_7 :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro


case mp
n : ‚Ñ§
‚ä¢ 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üí 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n
case mpr
n : ‚Ñ§
‚ä¢ 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n ‚Üí 6 ‚à£ n


For the left-to-right direction, we assume 6 ‚à£ n, and since the definition of this assumption is an existential statement, we immediately apply existential instantiation.


theorem Theorem_3_4_7 :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : 6 ‚à£ n; define at h1
  obtain (k : Int) (h2 : n = 6 * k) from h1


case mp
n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, n = 6 * c
k : ‚Ñ§
h2 : n = 6 * k
‚ä¢ 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n


Our goal is now a conjunction, so we prove the two conjuncts separately. Focusing just on the first one, 2 ‚à£ n, we write out the definition to decide how to proceed.


theorem Theorem_3_4_7 :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : 6 ‚à£ n; define at h1
  obtain (k : Int) (h2 : n = 6 * k) from h1
  apply And.intro
  define


case mp.left
n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, n = 6 * c
k : ‚Ñ§
h2 : n = 6 * k
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ c, n = 2 * c


Since we have n = 6 * k = 2 * 3 * k, it looks like 3 * k is the value we should use for c.


theorem Theorem_3_4_7 :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : 6 ‚à£ n; define at h1
  obtain (k : Int) (h2 : n = 6 * k) from h1
  apply And.intro
  define
  apply Exists.intro (3 * k)


case mp.left
n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, n = 6 * c
k : ‚Ñ§
h2 : n = 6 * k
‚ä¢ n = 2 * (3 * k)


Once again, if you think carefully about it, you will see that in order to deduce the goal from h2, we will need to use the associativity of multiplication to rewrite the goal as n = 2 * 3 * k. As we have already seen, mul_assoc 2 3 k is a proof of 2 * 3 * k = 2 * (3 * k). Since we want to replace the right side of this equation with the left in the goal, we‚Äôll use the tactic rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 2 3 k].


theorem Theorem_3_4_7 :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : 6 ‚à£ n; define at h1
  obtain (k : Int) (h2 : n = 6 * k) from h1
  apply And.intro
  define
  apply Exists.intro (3 * k)
  rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 2 3 k]


case mp.left
n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, n = 6 * c
k : ‚Ñ§
h2 : n = 6 * k
‚ä¢ n = 2 * 3 * k


Do we have to convince Lean that 2 * 3 = 6? No, remember that Lean works out definitions on its own. Lean knows the definition of multiplication, and it knows that, according to that definition, 2 * 3 is equal to 6. So it regards n = 6 * k and n = 2 * 3 * k as definitionally equal, and therefore it will recognize h2 as a proof of the goal.


theorem Theorem_3_4_7 :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : 6 ‚à£ n; define at h1
  obtain (k : Int) (h2 : n = 6 * k) from h1
  apply And.intro
  define
  apply Exists.intro (3 * k)
  rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 2 3 k]
  show n = 2 * 3 * k from h2


case mp.right
n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : ‚àÉ c, n = 6 * c
k : ‚Ñ§
h2 : n = 6 * k
‚ä¢ 3 ‚à£ n


The proof of the next goal, 3 ‚à£ n, is similar, and it completes the left-to-right direction of the biconditional.


theorem Theorem_3_4_7 :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : 6 ‚à£ n; define at h1
  obtain (k : Int) (h2 : n = 6 * k) from h1
  apply And.intro
  define
  apply Exists.intro (3 * k)
  rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 2 3 k]
  show n = 2 * 3 * k from h2
  define
  apply Exists.intro (2 * k)
  rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 3 2 k]
  show n = 3 * 2 * k from h2


case mpr
n : ‚Ñ§
‚ä¢ 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n ‚Üí 6 ‚à£ n


For the right-to-left direction, we begin by assuming 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n. We write out the definitions of 2 ‚à£ n and 3 ‚à£ n, and since this gives us two existential givens, we apply existential instantiation twice. To save space, we won‚Äôt repeat the proof of the first half of the proof in the displays below.


theorem Theorem_3_4_7 :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  ...
  -- (‚Üê)
  assume h1
  have h2 := h1.left
  have h3 := h1.right
  define at h2; define at h3; define
  obtain (j : Int) (h4 : n = 2 * j) from h2
  obtain (k : Int) (h5 : n = 3 * k) from h3


case mpr
n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n
h2 : ‚àÉ c, n = 2 * c
h3 : ‚àÉ c, n = 3 * c
j : ‚Ñ§
h4 : n = 2 * j
k : ‚Ñ§
h5 : n = 3 * k
‚ä¢ ‚àÉ c, n = 6 * c


The next step in the HTPI proof is a string of equations that proves \(6(j - k) = n\), which establishes that \(6 \mid n\). Let‚Äôs try to do the same thing in Lean, using a calculational proof:


theorem ??Theorem_3_4_7:: :
    ‚àÄ (n : Int), 6 ‚à£ n ‚Üî 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n := by
  fix n : Int
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  ...
  -- (‚Üê)
  assume h1
  have h2 := h1.left
  have h3 := h1.right
  define at h2; define at h3; define
  obtain (j : Int) (h4 : n = 2 * j) from h2
  obtain (k : Int) (h5 : n = 3 * k) from h3
  have h6 : 6 * (j - k) = n :=
    calc
      6 * (j - k) = 6 * j - 6 * k := sorry
      _ = 3 * (2 * j) - 2 * (3 * k) := sorry
      _ = 3 * n - 2 * n := sorry
      _ = (3 - 2) * n := sorry
      _ = n := sorry
  show ‚àÉ (c : Int), n = 6 * c
    from Exists.intro (j - k) h6.symm


>>Goals accomplished üéâ


Sometimes the easiest way to write a calculational proof is to justify each line with sorry and then go back and fill in real justifications. Lean has accepted the proof above, so we know that we‚Äôll have a complete proof if we can replace each sorry with a justification.
To justify the first line of the calculational proof, try replacing sorry with by library_search. Lean comes up with a justification: exact Int.mul_sub 6 j k, and #check Int.mul_sub produces the result

Int.mul_sub : ‚àÄ (a b c : ‚Ñ§), a * (b - c) = a * b - a * c.

Thus we can fill in Int.mul_sub 6 j k as a proof of the first equation.
It looks like we‚Äôll have to use the associativity of multiplication again to prove the second equation, but it will take more than one step. Let‚Äôs try writing a tactic-mode proof. In the display below, we‚Äôll just focus on the calculational proof.


have h6 : 6 * (j - k) = n :=
  calc
    6 * (j - k) = 6 * j - 6 * k := Int.mul_sub 6 j k
    _ = 3 * (2 * j) - 2 * (3 * k) := by

          **done::
    _ = 3 * n - 2 * n := sorry
    _ = (3 - 2) * n := sorry
    _ = n := sorry


n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n
h2 : ‚àÉ c, n = 2 * c
h3 : ‚àÉ c, n = 3 * c
j : ‚Ñ§
h4 : n = 2 * j
k : ‚Ñ§
h5 : n = 3 * k
‚ä¢ 6 * j - 6 * k =
>>  3 * (2 * j) -
>>    2 * (3 * k)


To justify the second equation, we‚Äôll have to use associativity to rewrite both 3 * (2 * j) as 3 * 2 * j and also 2 * (3 * k) as 2 * 3 * k. So we apply the rewrite tactic to both of the proofs mul_assoc 3 2 j : 3 * 2 * j = 3 * (2 * j) and mul_assoc 2 3 k : 2 * 3 * k = 2 * (3 * k):


have h6 : 6 * (j - k) = n :=
  calc
    6 * (j - k) = 6 * j - 6 * k := Int.mul_sub 6 j k
    _ = 3 * (2 * j) - 2 * (3 * k) := by
          rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 3 2 j]
          rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 2 3 k]
          **done::
    _ = 3 * n - 2 * n := sorry
    _ = (3 - 2) * n := sorry
    _ = n := sorry


n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n
h2 : ‚àÉ c, n = 2 * c
h3 : ‚àÉ c, n = 3 * c
j : ‚Ñ§
h4 : n = 2 * j
k : ‚Ñ§
h5 : n = 3 * k
‚ä¢ 6 * j - 6 * k =
>>  3 * 2 * j - 
>>    2 * 3 * k


To finish off the justification of the second equation, we‚Äôll use the theorem Eq.refl. The command #check Eq.refl gives the result Eq.refl : ‚àÄ (a : ?m.80342), a = a. This should remind you of the theorem Iff.refl : ‚àÄ (a : Prop), a ‚ÜîÔ∏é a. Recall that we were able to use Iff.refl _ to prove not only any statement of the form a ‚ÜîÔ∏é a, but also statements of the form a ‚ÜîÔ∏é a', where a and a' are definitionally equal. Similarly, Eq.refl _ will prove any equation of the form a = a', where a and a' are definitionally equal. Since Lean knows that, by definition, 3 * 2 = 6 and 2 * 3 = 6, the goal has this form. Thus we can complete the proof with the tactic show 6 * j - 6 * k = 3 * 2 * j - 2 * 3 * k from Eq.refl _. As we saw earlier, a shorter version of this would be exact Eq.refl _. But this situation comes up often enough that there is an even shorter version: the tactic rfl can be used as a shorthand for either exact Eq.refl _ or exact Iff.refl _. In other words, in a tactic-mode proof, if the goal has one of the forms a = a' or a ‚ÜîÔ∏é a', where a and a' are definitionally equal, then the tactic rfl will prove the goal. So rfl will finish off the justification of the second equation, and we can move on to the third.


have h6 : 6 * (j - k) = n :=
  calc
    6 * (j - k) = 6 * j - 6 * k := Int.mul_sub 6 j k
    _ = 3 * (2 * j) - 2 * (3 * k) := by
          rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 3 2 j]
          rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 2 3 k]
          rfl
          done
    _ = 3 * n - 2 * n := by

          **done::
    _ = (3 - 2) * n := sorry
    _ = n := sorry


n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n
h2 : ‚àÉ c, n = 2 * c
h3 : ‚àÉ c, n = 3 * c
j : ‚Ñ§
h4 : n = 2 * j
k : ‚Ñ§
h5 : n = 3 * k
‚ä¢ 3 * (2 * j) -
>>  2 * (3 * k) =
>>    3 * n - 2 * n


To justify the third equation we have to substitute n for both 2 * j and 3 * k. We can use h4 and h5 in the rewrite tactic to do this. In fact, we can do it in one step: you can put a list of proofs of equations or biconditionals inside the brackets, and the rewrite tactic will perform all of the replacements, one after another. In our case, the tactic rewrite [h4, h5] will first replace 2 * j in the goal with n, and then it will replace 3 * k with n.


have h6 : 6 * (j - k) = n :=
  calc
    6 * (j - k) = 6 * j - 6 * k := Int.mul_sub 6 j k
    _ = 3 * (2 * j) - 2 * (3 * k) := by
          rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 3 2 j]
          rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 2 3 k]
          rfl
          done
    _ = 3 * n - 2 * n := by
          rewrite [‚Üêh4, ‚Üêh5]
          **done::
    _ = (3 - 2) * n := sorry
    _ = n := sorry


n : ‚Ñ§
h1 : 2 ‚à£ n ‚àß 3 ‚à£ n
h2 : ‚àÉ c, n = 2 * c
h3 : ‚àÉ c, n = 3 * c
j : ‚Ñ§
h4 : n = 2 * j
k : ‚Ñ§
h5 : n = 3 * k
‚ä¢ 3 * n - 2 * n =
>>  3 * n - 2 * n


Of course, the rfl tactic will now finish off the justification of the third equation.
The fourth equation is 3 * n - 2 * n = (3 - 2) * n. It looks like the algebraic law we need to justify this is a lot like the one that was used in the first equation, but with the subtraction to the left of the multiplication rather than to the right. It shouldn‚Äôt be surprising, therefore, that the name of the theorem we need is Int.sub_mul. The command #check Int.sub_mul gives the response

Int.sub_mul : ‚àÄ (a b c : ‚Ñ§), (a - b) * c = a * c - b * c,

so Int.sub_mul 3 2 n is a proof of (3 - 2) * n = 3 * n - 2 * n. But the fourth equation has the sides of this equation reversed, so to justify it we need (Int.sub_mul 3 2 n).symm.
Finally, the fifth equation is (3 - 2) * n = n. Why is this true? Because it is definitionally equal to 1 * n = n. Is there a theorem to justify this last equation? One way to find the answer is to type in this example:
example (n : Int) : 1 * n = n := by ##library_search::
Lean responds with exact one_mul n, and #check one_mul yields one_mul : ‚àÄ (a : ?m.73050), 1 * a = a. So one_mul n should justify the last equation. Here‚Äôs the complete calculational proof, where we have shortened the second step a bit by doing both rewrites in one step:
  have h6 : 6 * (j - k) = n :=
    calc
      6 * (j - k) = 6 * j - 6 * k := Int.mul_sub 6 j k
      _ = 3 * (2 * j) - 2 * (3 * k) := by
            rewrite [‚Üêmul_assoc 3 2 j, ‚Üêmul_assoc 2 3 k]; rfl
      _ = 3 * n - 2 * n := by rewrite [‚Üêh4, ‚Üêh5]; rfl
      _ = (3 - 2) * n := (Int.sub_mul 3 2 n).symm
      _ = n := one_mul n
Whew! This example illustrates why algebraic reasoning in Lean can be difficult. But one reason why this proof was challenging is that we justified all of our steps from basic algebraic principles. Fortunately, there are more powerful tactics that can automate some algebraic reasoning. For example, the tactic ring can combine algebraic laws involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and exponentiation with natural number exponents to prove many equations in one step. Also, the tactic rw is a variant of rewrite that automatically applies rfl after the rewriting if it can be used to finish the proof. Here‚Äôs a shortened version of our calculational proof that uses these tactics.
  have h6 : 6 * (j - k) = n :=
    calc
      6 * (j - k) = 3 * (2 * j) - 2 * (3 * k) := by ring
      _ = 3 * n - 2 * n := by rw [‚Üêh4, ‚Üêh5]
      _ = n := by ring

4.1. Ordered Pairs and Cartesian Products
Section 4.1 of How To Prove It defines the Cartesian product \(A \times B\) of two sets \(A\) and \(B\) to be the set of all ordered pairs \((a, b)\), where \(a \in A\) and \(b \in B\). However, in Lean, Cartesian product is an operation on types, not sets. If A and B are types, then A √ó B is the type of ordered pairs (a, b), where a has type A and b has type B. In other words, if you have a : A and b : B, then (a, b) is an object of type A √ó B. There is also notation for the first and second coordinates of an ordered pair. If p has type A √ó B, then p.1 is the first coordinate of p, and p.2 is the second coordinate. In other words, p = (p.1, p.2). You can also use the notation p.fst for the first coordinate of p and p.snd for the second coordinate.

title: 4¬† Relations
text:
4.2. Relations
Section 4.2 of HTPI defines a relation from \(A\) to \(B\) to be a subset of \(A \times B\). In other words, if \(R\) is a relation from \(A\) to \(B\), then \(R\) is a set whose element are ordered pairs \((a, b)\), where \(a \in A\) and \(b \in B\). We will see in the next section that in Lean, it is convenient to use a somewhat different definition of relations. Nevertheless, we will take some time in this section to study sets of ordered pairs. If A and B are types, and R is a set whose elements are ordered pairs (a, b), where a has type A and b has type B, then R has type Set (A √ó B).
Section 4.2 of HTPI discusses several concepts concerning relations. Here is how these concepts are defined in HTPI:

Suppose \(R\) is a relation from \(A\) to \(B\). Then the domain of \(R\) is the set

\(\text{Dom}(R) = \{a \in A \mid \exists b \in B((a, b) \in R)\}\).

The range of \(R\) is the set

\(\text{Ran}(R) = \{b \in B \mid \exists a \in A((a, b) \in R)\}\).

The inverse of \(R\) is the relation \(R^{-1}\) from \(B\) to \(A\) define as follows:

\(R^{-1} = \{(b, a) \in B \times A \mid (a, b) \in R\}\).

Finally, suppose \(R\) is a relation from \(A\) to \(B\) and \(S\) is a relation from \(B\) to \(C\). Then the composition of \(S\) and \(R\) is the relation \(S \circ R\) from \(A\) to \(C\) defined as follows:

\(S \circ R = \{(a, c) \in A \times C \mid \exists b \in B((a, b) \in R \text{ and } (b, c) \in S)\}\).


We can write corresponding definitions in Lean as follows:
def Dom {A B : Type} (R : Set (A √ó B)) : Set A :=
    {a : A | ‚àÉ (b : B), (a, b) ‚àà R}
def Ran {A B : Type} (R : Set (A √ó B)) : Set B :=
    {b : B | ‚àÉ (a : A), (a, b) ‚àà R}
def inv {A B : Type} (R : Set (A √ó B)) : Set (B √ó A) :=
    {p : B √ó A | (p.2, p.1) ‚àà R}
def comp {A B C : Type} (S : Set (B √ó C)) (R : Set (A √ó B)) :
    Set (A √ó C) := {p : A √ó C | ‚àÉ (b : B), (p.1, b) ‚àà R ‚àß (b, p.2) ‚àà S}
Definitions in Lean are introduced with the keyword def. In the definition of Dom, we have declared A and B to be implicit parameters. That means that if we have R : Set (A √ó B), then we can just write Dom R for the domain of R, and Lean will figure out for itself what A and B are. The definition declares that Dom R has type Set A, and then it defines it to be the set of all objects a of type A such that there is some b of type B with (a, b) ‚àà R. This is a direct translation, into Lean‚Äôs type-theory language, of the first part of Definition 4.2.3. The other three definitions are similar; they define Ran R to be the range of R, inv R to be the inverse of R, and comp S R to be the composition of S and R.
Here is the main theorem about these concepts, as stated in HTPI:

Suppose \(R\) is a relation from \(A\) to \(B\), \(S\) is a relation from \(B\) to \(C\), and \(T\) is a relation from \(C\) to \(D\). Then:

\((R^{-1})^{-1} = R\).
\(\mathrm{Dom}(R^{-1}) = \mathrm{Ran}(R)\).
\(\mathrm{Ran}(R^{-1}) = \mathrm{Dom}(R)\).
\(T \circ (S \circ R) = (T \circ S) \circ R\).
\((S \circ R)^{-1} = R^{-1} \circ S^{-1}\).


All five parts of this theorem follow directly from the definitions of the relevant concepts. In fact, in the first three parts, Lean recognizes the two sides of the equation as being definitionally equal, and therefore the tactic rfl proves those parts:
theorem Theorem_4_2_5_1 {A B : Type}
    (R : Set (A √ó B)) : inv (inv R) = R := by rfl

theorem Theorem_4_2_5_2 {A B : Type}
    (R : Set (A √ó B)) : Dom (inv R) = Ran R := by rfl

theorem Theorem_4_2_5_3 {A B : Type}
    (R : Set (A √ó B)) : Ran (inv R) = Dom R := by rfl
The fourth part will take a little more work to prove. Here is a natural way to start the proof:
theorem Theorem_4_2_5_4 {A B C : Type}
    (R : Set (A √ó B)) (S : Set (B √ó C)) (T : Set (C √ó D)) :
    comp T (comp S R) = comp (comp T S) R := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix (a, d) : A √ó D
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : (a, d) ‚àà comp T (comp S R)
  define at h1
After the apply Set.ext tactic, the goal is

‚àÄ (x : A √ó D), x ‚àà comp T (comp S R) ‚ÜîÔ∏é x ‚àà comp (comp T S) R

The next step should be to introduce an arbitrary object of type A √ó D. We could just call this object x, but Lean let‚Äôs us use a shortcut here. An object of type A √ó D must have the form of an ordered pair, where the first coordinate has type A and the second has type D. So Lean let‚Äôs us write it as an ordered pair right away. That‚Äôs what we‚Äôve done in the second step, fix (a, d) : A √ó D. This tactic introduces two new variables into the proof, a : A and d : D. (The proof in HTPI uses a similar shortcut.)
After introducing the arbitrary ordered pair (a, d), we must prove a biconditional statement, so we try to prove the two directions separately. For the left-to-right direction, we assume h1 : (a, d) ‚àà comp T (comp S R), and we must prove (a, d) ‚àà comp (comp T S) R. When we ask Lean to write out the definition of the goal, the result is:

‚àÉ b, ((a, d).fst, b) ‚àà R ‚àß (b, (a, d).snd) ‚àà comp T S

Usually, the define tactic does a good job of writing out definitions, but in this case it has let us down a bit. The definition isn‚Äôt wrong, but it‚Äôs not written in the most convenient form. We can improve on the result by using the tactics define : (a, d).fst and define : (a, d).snd, which put the goal into this form:

‚àÉ b, (a, b) ‚àà R ‚àß (b, d) ‚àà comp T S

That solves the problem‚Äîthis time. But we‚Äôre going to have to write out the definition of composition of relations several more times in this proof; will we have to fix Lean‚Äôs awkward definition every time?
A better idea is to teach Lean to do a better job of using the definition of composition. We can do that by proving a preliminary theorem before proving part 4 of Theorem 4.2.5:
theorem simp_comp
    {A B C : Type} (S : Set (B √ó C)) (R : Set (A √ó B)) (a : A) (c : C) :
    (a, c) ‚àà comp S R ‚Üî ‚àÉ (x : B), (a, x) ‚àà R ‚àß (x, c) ‚àà S := by rfl
Now, any time we have relations R : Set (A √ó B) and S : (B √ó C), and objects a : A and c : C, the expression simp_comp S R a c will be a proof of the statement (a, c) ‚àà comp S R ‚ÜîÔ∏é ‚àÉ (x : B), (a, x) ‚àà R ‚àß (x, c) ‚àà S. And that means that the tactic rewrite [simp_comp S R a c] will change (a, c) ‚àà comp S R to ‚àÉ (x : B), (a, x) ‚àà R ‚àß (x, c) ‚àà S, exactly as we wanted. In fact, as we‚Äôve seen before, you can just write rewrite [simp_comp], and Lean will figure out how to apply the theorem simp_comp to rewrite some part of the goal.
Actually, it‚Äôs more convenient to do the rewriting before the step apply Iff.intro‚Äîotherwise we‚Äôd have to do it twice, once for each direction of the biconditional proof. So now we start the proof like this:
theorem Theorem_4_2_5_4 {A B C : Type}
    (R : Set (A √ó B)) (S : Set (B √ó C)) (T : Set (C √ó D)) :
    comp T (comp S R) = comp (comp T S) R := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix (a, d) : A √ó D
  rewrite [simp_comp, simp_comp]
Why did we list simp_comp twice in the rewrite tactic? After the step fix (a, d) : A √ó D, the goal is

(a, d) ‚àà comp T (comp S R) ‚ÜîÔ∏é (a, d) ‚àà comp (comp T S) R

When we ask Lean to use the theorem simp_comp, it figures out that simp_comp T (comp S R) a d is a proof of the statement

(a, d) ‚àà comp T (comp S R) ‚ÜîÔ∏é ‚àÉ (x : C), (a, x) ‚àà comp S R ‚àß (x, d) ‚àà T,

which can be used to rewrite the left-hand side of the goal. To rewrite the right-hand side, we need a different application of the simp_comp theorem, simp_comp (comp T S) R a d. So we have to ask Lean to apply the theorem a second time.
Here is the complete proof.
theorem Theorem_4_2_5_4 {A B C : Type}
    (R : Set (A √ó B)) (S : Set (B √ó C)) (T : Set (C √ó D)) :
    comp T (comp S R) = comp (comp T S) R := by
  apply Set.ext
  fix (a, d) : A √ó D
  rewrite [simp_comp, simp_comp]
    --Goal:  (‚àÉ (x : C), (a, x) ‚àà comp S R ‚àß (x, d) ‚àà T) ‚Üî
    --           ‚àÉ (x : B), (a, x) ‚àà R ‚àß (x, d) ‚àà comp T S
  apply Iff.intro
  -- (‚Üí)
  assume h1 : ‚àÉ (x : C), (a, x) ‚àà comp S R ‚àß (x, d) ‚àà T
  obtain (c : C) (h2 : (a, c) ‚àà comp S R ‚àß (c, d) ‚àà T) from h1
  rewrite [simp_comp] at h2
    --h2: (‚àÉ (x : B), (a, x) ‚àà R ‚àß (x, c) ‚àà S) ‚àß (c, d) ‚àà T
  obtain (b : B) (h3 : (a, b) ‚àà R ‚àß (b, c) ‚àà S) from h2.left
  apply Exists.intro b --Goal:  (a, b) ‚àà R ‚àß (b, d) ‚àà comp T S
  apply And.intro h3.left
  rewrite [simp_comp]  --Goal:  ‚àÉ (x : C), (b, x) ‚àà S ‚àß (x, d) ‚àà T
  show ‚àÉ (x : C), (b, x) ‚àà S ‚àß (x, d) ‚àà T from
    Exists.intro c (And.intro h3.right h2.right)
  -- (‚Üê)
  assume h1 : ‚àÉ (x : B), (a, x) ‚àà R ‚àß (x, d) ‚àà comp T S
  obtain (b : B) (h2 : (a, b) ‚àà R ‚àß (b, d) ‚àà comp T S) from h1
  rewrite [simp_comp] at h2
  obtain (c : C) (h3 : (b, c) ‚àà S ‚àß (c, d) ‚àà T) from h2.right
  apply Exists.intro c
  apply And.intro _ h3.right
  rewrite [simp_comp]
  show ‚àÉ (x : B), (a, x) ‚àà R ‚àß (x, c) ‚àà S from
    Exists.intro b (And.intro h2.left h3.left)
Of course, if you have trouble reading this proof, you can type it into Lean and see how the tactic state changes over the course of the proof.
